name: The 50th Issue
description: 50 Years. 50 Frames. 50 Writers. 50 Artists. Little White Lies 50 offers a unique celebration of the last 50 years of cinema, as interpreted by some of the best film writers, makers and artists working today. For this one-off anniversary edition we've stripped away all the usual features and reviews content, assigning 50 guest contributors a year between 1964 and 2013. They were then tasked with choosing a film from that year and finally a single frame from that film. Where each contributor went next was totally up to them. To accompany each entry, 50 bespoke illustrations were also commissioned, comprising a wide array of seriously awesome design talent. Entries include: -Rian Johnson, director of Looper, on his Scorsese screen epiphany. -France's Mia Hansen-Løve finds the essence of cinema in a modern Japanese love story. -Lukas Moodysson lauds a Romanian New Wave classic. -Norway's Joachim Trier invites his favourite director, Arnaud Desplechin, for a cup of coffee. -Chinese luminary Jia Zhang-ke says why '80s dance movie, Breakin', made him the man he is today. Plus, read about David Lynch's last great movie, a love letter to Faye Dunaway, the faded London in Michael Tuchner's Villain and the ghost of Three Men and a Baby. UK postage & handling is £2 (+ £1 for each additional issue), £4.50 for EU addresses (+ £1 for each additional issue) and £6.90 for the Rest of the World (+ £2.75 for each additional issue).

name: The Blue Jasmine Issue *SOLD OUT*
description: James McAvoy wallows in Filth; Clio Barnard summons The Selfish Giant; Joe Lawlor and Christine Molloy address Mister John; Hirokazu Koreeda discovers Like Father, Like Son; Casey Affleck and Rooney Mara whisper Ain't Them Bodies Saints; Chris Hemsworth gets a Rush; Channing Tatum and Jamie Foxx resist White House Down; Paulo Sorrentino ponders The Great Beauty; and Hong Sang-soo cherishes Nobody's Daughter Hae-Won. Inspired by our feature film: Woody's Women: From Keaton to Cate Blanchett, how the cinema of Woody Allen is defined by his relationship with the opposite sex. Streetcar Stories: Tennesse Williams' enduring tale of love and death in the Deep South, A Streetcar Name continues to leave its mark on modern cinema. Type Casting: Inspired by Woody Allen's typographic monogamy, legendary movie title designer Dan Perri shares the amazing stories behind his most famous creations. The Art of Defending Woody: Woody Allen has made his share of bad movies, but there's no shortage of people willing to stand behind them. Plus exclusive interviews with James McAvoy, Casey Affleck, John Akomfah, Clio Barnard, Kevin Macdonald and Slavoj Žižek. UK postage & handling is £2 (+ £1 for each additional issue), £4.50 for EU addresses (+ £1 for each additional issue) and £6.90 for the Rest of the World (+ £2.75 for each additional issue).

name: The Elysium Issue
description: Ryan Gosling discovers Only God Forgives; Emma Watson joins The Bling Ring; Shane Carruth envisions Upstream Color; Greta Gerwig is Frances Ha; Amanda Seyfried undresses Lovelace; Ben Wheatley visits A Field In England; Johnny Depp meets The Lone Ranger; Disney/Pixar enrol at Monsters University; Michael Bay endures Pain & Gain; and Ulrich Seidl presents his Paradise trilogy. Inspired by our feature film: Man Vs Machine: Can director Neill Blomkamp survive inside Hollywood? Utopia / Dystopia: Inverse visions of mankind's future Full Metal Jacket: How exoskeleton technology is transcending science fiction That Syncing Feeling: Downloading Elysium stars Matt Damon and Sharlto Copley Star City: How close are we to the great space migration? Saffa's Sci-Fi Shame!: The amazing story of the worst space movie ever made Live Forever: Discover the amazing technologies changing medical science Plus exclusive interviews with Sofia Coppola & Emma Watson, Nicolas Winding Refn, Shane Carruth, Greta Gerwig and Gore Verbinski. UK postage & handling is £2 (+ £1 for each additional issue), £5 for EU addresses (+ £1 for each additional issue) and £6 for the Rest of the World (+ £2.75 for each additional issue).

name: The Man of Steel Issue
description: To start a subscription with Man Of Steel, use the promotional code CURRENT on our subscription page Pedro Almodóvar screams I'm So Excited; Olivier Assayas senses Something in The Air; Michael Shannon is The Iceman; Abbas Kiarostami behaves Like Someone In Love; Joss Whedon proclaims Much Ado About Nothing; Richard Linklater falls in love Before Midnight; Matthew McConaughey is Mud; Viggo Mortensen ensures Everybody Has A Plan; and Neil Jordan evokes Byzantium. Inspired by our feature film: Zack To Front: LWLies takes a serious look at Man Of Steel director Zack Snyder Apex Twin: Man Of Steel's creative other-half Christopher Nolan hopes to give us the best of both worlds Amazing Adventures: The true-story of two boys who invented America's greatest superhero Is It A Bird, Is It A Plane?: LWLies exposes Superman's true identity No More Mr Nice Guy: Outrageous vintage comic-book covers reveal Superman's dark side Woman Of Steel: Getting to know the amazing women who inspired Lois Lane How Superman Defeated The Ku Klux Klan: How a hero with a secret identity overcame a gang of masked villains Bored To Tears: Five great reinventions of Superman Plus exclusive interviews with Jeff Nichols and Olivier Assayas UK postage & handling is £2 (+ £1 for each additional issue), £4 for EU addresses (+ £1 for each additional issue) and £6 for the Rest of the World (+ £2.75 for each additional issue).

name: Little White Lies Icons of Cinema T-shirt
description: - Original illustration by Paul Willoughby - Silk screen printed in London - 100% cotton Fair Trade T-shirt Stocks limited, available in S, M & L (Size Guide) Posted recorded 'signed for' (UK) and International 'signed for' (EU/ROW). UK postage & handling is £4 (+ £1 for each additional shirt), £8.50 for EU addresses (+ £1.50 for each additional shirt) and £10 for the Rest of the World (+ £2 for each additional shirt). Wrong size? Depending on availability, only clean, unworn shirts in their original condition can be exchanged. See our returns page for details.

name: Live for Myself, Answer to Nobody
description: LWLies is proud to partner a magazine tribute to Steve McQueen in collaboration with The Vinyl Factory and Mach Schau. ‘Live for Myself, Answer to Nobody’ reveals unseen photographs of McQueen by Barry Feinstein, alongside contemporary artists’ own work, dealing with the overarching theme of the ‘Outsider’ and rebel culture. The exhibition featuring in Soho, London from November 28th - January 14th will expand on the imagery shown in this magazine and prints will be available to purchase, as well as other Steve McQueen related materials.

name: The Django Unchained Issue
description: Judd Apatow accepts This Is 40; Ang Lee ponders Life Of Pi; Daniel Day-Lewis is Lincoln; Kathryn Bigelow declassifies Zero Dark Thirty; Pablo Larraín and Gael García Bernal say No; Denzel Washington takes Flight; the Wachowski brothers chart Cloud Atlas; Naomi Watts does The Impossible; John Hawkes and Helen Hunt schedule The Sessions and Terrence Malick journeys To The Wonder. Inspired by our feature film: Films, fear, feet: Quentin Tarantino talks exclusively to LWLies about his quest to be remembered as one of the greatest directors of all time. Bang, bang, he shot me down: Django Unchained's legendary special-effects expert breaks down the bloody anatomy of a movie gunshot. Discover the real Django: An original graphic novel about the amazing true story of a black slave who became an Injun-killin', steer-wranglin', whiskey-sluggin' cowboy. Franco Nero The legendary actor who inspired Django Unchained reveals what it's like to be worshiped by Tarantino (and what's in Luis Buñuel's lunch box). Western spaghetti What is Tarantino's favourite film and how did it influence six decades of cinema? Everything is a Western Why The Dark Knight Rises, Point Break and Heat are all just a little bit of history repeating. Plus interviews with John Hawkes and Pablo Larraín. UK postage & handling is £2 (+ £1 for each additional issue), £4 for EU addresses (+ £1 for each additional issue) and £6 for the Rest of the World (+ £2.75 for each additional issue). Please note: We can not guarantee delivery in time for Christmas for any orders placed from the 20th December.

name: The Master issue *SOLD OUT*
description: Ben Wheatley, Alice Lowe and Steve Oram are Sightseers, Michael Haneke whispers Amour, Chris O'Dowd flaunts The Sapphires, Ben Affleck plots Argo, Clint Eastwood sees Trouble With the Curve, Cristi Piui ushers Aurora, David O Russell writes his Silver Linings Playbook, Jacques Audiard welds Rust and Bone, Xavier Dolan does Laurence Anyways, Yorgos Lanthimos scales Alps, and Martin McDonagh and Colin Farrell size up Seven Psychopaths. Inspired by our feature film: Processing PTA - A partial portrait of Hollywood's most enigmatic filmmaker. The Scoop: PTA's producing partner gives us the 411 on his creative process. Hoffman's Choice: Philip Seymour Hoffman on becoming the master. Going Long: Celebrating 70mm and the tangible joys of film. Utopian Visions: Macabre motifs and cult iconography courtesy of Mark Ryden. Searching for Bergman: LWLies travels to Fårö on the trail of Sweden's enigmatic master Get With the Programme: Ex-cult members reveal how they escaped the clutches of madness. Plus interviews with Alice Lowe and Steve Oram, Martin McDonagh and Yorgos Lanthimos. UK postage & handling is £2 (+ £1 for each additional issue), £4 for EU addresses (+ £1 for each additional issue) and £6 for the Rest of the World (+ £2.75 for each additional issue).

name: The On the Road Issue *SOLD OUT*
description: **Single issues are sold out!** Joseph Gordon-Levitt has a time crisis in Looper; Andrew Dominik and Brad Pitt forgo Killing Them Softly; Guy Maddin peeks through Keyhole; Karl Urban is Dredd; Christian Petzold banishes Barbara; Leos Carax revs up Holy Motors; Woody Allen travels To Rome with Love; and Miguel Gomes looks back in Tabu. Inspired by our feature films: Director’s commentary: Walter Salles on improvisation, adventure and the tension between freedom and family The Book of Kristen: Silence, please, for the world's most talked-about actress The Man Who Would Be King: Is Garrett Hedlund Hollywood's next big superstar The Beat Bookshelf: Peruse the ultimate hipster's library Searching for Bergman: LWLies travels to Fårö on the trail of Sweden's enigmatic master American Outlaw: Rediscovering the work of Shirley Clarke The Beat Goes On: A visual celebration of a century's radical individualism Reliving Paradise: The view from the tracks with a modern-day hobo Plus interviews with Rian Johnson, Guy Maddin and Miguel Gomes. UK postage & handling is £2 (+ £1 for each additional issue), £4 for EU addresses (+ £1 for each additional issue) and £6 for the Rest of the World (+ £2.75 for each additional issue).

name: The Lawless Issue *SOLD OUT*
description: Andrea Riseborough tickles our fancy in Shadow Dancer; Bobcat Goldthwait hollers God Bless America; Pixar get Brave; Channing Tatum bares all for Magic Mike; Andrew Garfield gets sticky in The Amazing Spider-Man; Patricio Guzmán discovers Nostalgia for the Light; Hitch is restored for The Lodger. Inspired by our feature films: Director’s commentary: John Hillcoat explains how on-set tension provided the spark for his bootlegging drama. No More Drama: Tom Hardy gets up in your grill. The Bondurant Boy: Wettest County author Matt Bondurant opens his scrapbook. Designing Old America: Four DPs reveal how their visions of vintage America made it to the big screen. This is History: A sepia-tinged photo folio of modern America. The (Un)Making of Horror: Meet the directors who faced hell and high water to make their dream nightmare movies. Original Spin: Nick Cave on the Lawless soundtrack. Shine On: Reinventing Franklin County’s finest hooch. Hammered & Sickle: How prohibition failed to save Russia from drowning in drink. Plus interviews with directors James Marsh, Andrew Kötting and Marc Webb. UK postage & handling is £2 (+ £1 for each additional issue), £4 for EU addresses (+ £1 for each additional issue) and £6 for the Rest of the World (+ £2.75 for each additional issue).
